Sport.title: Sport
Sport.description: Represents a sport in the UniSport Central system.

id.description: Unique identifier for the sport entity.

sportName.description: The name of the sport (e.g., Cricket, Football).

teamSize.description: The default team size for the sport.

defaultDurationMinutes.description: The default duration of a match in minutes for the sport.

Venue.title: Venue
Venue.description: Represents a venue where sports events are held.

id.description: Unique identifier for the venue entity.

name.description: The name of the venue (e.g., Main Ground).

reservations.description: A list of reservations for the venue.

Event.title: Event
Event.description: Represents a sports event or tournament.

id.description: Unique identifier for the event entity.

sportType.description: The type of sport for the event.

startDate.description: The start date of the event.

durationDays.description: The duration of the event in days.

Team.title: Team
Team.description: Represents a team participating in an event.

id.description: Unique identifier for the team entity.

department.description: The department the team belongs to.

sportType.description: The type of sport the team plays.

preferredVenues.description: A list of preferred venues for the team.

Match.title: Match
Match.description: Represents a match between two teams in an event.

id.description: Unique identifier for the match entity.

teamAId.description: Reference to Team. (Relationship: Team 1:N Match as Team A)

teamBId.description: Reference to Team. (Relationship: Team 1:N Match as Team B)

sportType.description: The type of sport for the match.

startTime.description: The start time of the match.

endTime.description: The end time of the match.

round.description: The round of the match in the tournament.

winnerTeamId.description: Reference to Team. (Relationship: Team 1:N Match as Winner)

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the UniSport Central system.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

displayName.description: The display name of the user.

role.description: The role of the user (admin, coordinator, referee, student).

dept.description: The department the user belongs to.

Log.title: Log
Log.description: Represents a log entry for an event.

id.description: Unique identifier for the log entry.

timestamp.description: The timestamp of the log entry.

definition.description: Stores details about each sport, such as name, team size, and default duration.
Stores information about each venue, including name, location, capacity, and reservations.
Stores details about each event, including name, sport type, department, start date, and settings.
Stores team information for a specific event. Includes denormalized 'eventId' to maintain authorization independence.
Stores match details for a specific event. Includes denormalized 'eventId' to maintain authorization independence.
Stores user profile information, including display name, role, department, and email.
Stores log entries for specific events, including messages and timestamps.

params.name: logId
params.description: Unique identifier for the log entry.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to support a sports event management system, UniSport Central, with a focus on clear authorization, scalability, and maintainability. Authorization Independence is achieved by denormalizing role information into user documents and event-specific access control lists within each event's subcollections where needed. Path-based ownership is used for user-specific data, such as user profiles. For collaborative data like events and matches, a membership map (`members`) is used where appropriate. This structure avoids complex `get()` calls in security rules, ensuring atomic operations and easier debugging. Segregation of data based on access needs (e.g., public events versus admin-managed events) simplifies security rules. QAPs are supported through structural segregation and controlled access via role-based permissions. For example, only admins can `create`, `update`, or `delete` events, while users can `read` public event data and, in some cases, create teams or register for events if their role permits.
